text: Arsenal have sold their best player for the second summer in succession but where there was fury and confusion last time after the departures of Cesc Fábregas and Samir Nasri, there is now optimism and excitement. Robin van Persie's goals will be missed but in signing Santi Cazorla, Lukas Podolski and Olivier Giroud, Arsenal have done more than merely limit the damage. The theory that the club might be collectively stronger faces its first test against a Sunderland side that will not boast many new faces but will endeavour to dampen the mood. David Hytner

The Norwich manager, Chris Hughton, has paid tribute to his Fulham counterpart, Martin Jol, whom he worked under for three years at Tottenham, ahead of Saturday's meeting. "I have learned a lot from him, so he has played a very good part in where I am in this moment," he said. Hughton, however, will be going all out to beat his friend, and much could hinge on the potential success of a new forward partnership between Grant Holt and Robert Snodgrass. With the unsettled forward Clint Dempsey not in the squad, Fulham will be looking to new signing Mladen Petric for goals, whilst Moussa Dembélé remaining at the club is a significant bonus. Alex Finnis

To Newcastle's Alan Pardew, André Villas-Boas's Tottenham currently remain as mysterious as Brendan Rodgers's Liverpool. "I'll be interested to see how Liverpool, with my friend Brendan there, evolve and it's the same with Spurs," said Pardew. "There have been big changes at Spurs. Will it be a positive or a negative? It will be interesting to see André's hand when it's delivered on Saturday." The former Chelsea manager's cause may be helped by home concerns surrounding the fitness of Papiss Cissé, Yohan Cabaye and Hatem Ben Arfa. Vurnon Anita, newly signed from Ajax, could make his Newcastle debut. Louise Taylor

Amid the bedlam created by Manchester City's late title triumph last season it was somewhat forgotten that their opponents on the day, Queens Park Rangers, had just avoided relegation. That was some feat for their manager, Mark Hughes, given the tough string of fixtures he faced upon taking the job in January. He will hope to progress in his first full season at the club, starting with a win against a team seeking to confound all expectations for a second successive season, but this time under the charge of Michael Laudrup. Sachin Nakrani

Stoke are arguably the most successful promoted side of recent years. Since joining the Premier League in 2008 the Potters have never been in a relegation battle, and Tony Pulis is keen to ensure this season is no different. "Gradually we're putting things into place that this football club could never have dreamed of and we mustn't get too greedy. Staying in the Premier League is our target," he said. Newly promoted Reading will be looking to emulate their opponents' top-flight staying power, but manager Brian McDermott may find himself with a tough task on his hands. New signing Pavel Pogrebnyak could be key – the Russian forward scored a goal every other game during his loan spell at Fulham last season and the Royals will hope he can replicate that form in 2012-13. Alex Finnis

A fresh start at The Hawthorns where Steve Clarke and Brendan Rodgers take charge of their new clubs for the first time in the Premier League. Rodgers had asked Clarke to stay with Liverpool when first approached to succeed Kenny Dalglish this summer before the matter was taken out of their hands. "I actually got sacked by Liverpool," Clarke revealed on Friday, insisting he has no grievance with his former employers. But it does add to the spice. Rodgers is Liverpool's fourth manager in four seasons and may need a positive start before facing Manchester City, Arsenal and Manchester United in his first three home games. Andy Hunter

West Ham are back in the Premier League and the task for their manager, Sam Allardyce, is clear – prevent the club suffering a fifth top-flight relegation in 24 years. He is aiming higher and wants his players to start the new campaign with a victory. That could prove tough against an Aston Villa side now under the charge of Paul Lambert, who, unlike his predecessor Alex McLeish, has the backing of the club's supporters. James Collins, who moved from Villa to West Ham in the summer, will make his home debut this afternoon. Sachin Nakrani

Southampton can take immense pride in the consecutive promotions with which Nigel Adkins has restored the club to the top flight, but this game might be seen as a trial for a club that has come so far so soon. It would be a surprise if Manchester City did not revel in the occasion at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday. The manager, Roberto Mancini, seemed frustrated this summer by a halt to the large-scale recruitment policy of the past, but a settled squad may be formidable as players improve their rapport with one another. Kevin McCarra

This has occasionally proved an awkward fixture for Chelsea in the recent past and, given the frailties that have reared in their defence in pre-season, will offer another stern test on Sunday lunchtime. The focus may be drawn to Victor Moses, who is coveted at Stamford Bridge and could move to London before the end of the transfer window, but the visitors would do well to concentrate on stifling the home debutant, Arouna Koné. Chelsea's own £20m new boy, Oscar, could feature in some capacity as Roberto Di Matteo marks his first Premier League game in full-time charge. Both managers would hope to start in the manner in which their sides finished last term. Dominic Fifield

Sir Alex Ferguson has sounded ebullient this week. There can be no doubt that the purchase of Robin van Persie from Arsenal gives him an array of forwards that others will envy, but the implication was that Manchester United are not receding into the shadows merely because Manchester City are Premier League champions. He was also indicating once more that he is at peace with the policies of the owners, the Glazers. Everton, however, could cause United disquiet on Monday night in a demanding fixture at Goodison. Kevin McCarra

In an effort to concentrate minds, Paul Lambert has banned his players from using their phones and laptops around Villa's training ground but more than that may be needed to get Aston Villa back on track. The hosts have won just one of their last 13 Premier League home matches and will not have been able to take too many positives from the defeat to West Ham. In more bad news for Villa fans, they are also facing an Everton side who will be full to brim with confidence after their impressive victory over Manchester United. Ian McCourt

It is too soon to tell what Chelsea will take from the season, but the departure of Didier Drogba could lead to greater variety in attack. Fernando Torres might now impose himself more, even if he was lucky not to have his goal disallowed for offside against Reading. The newcomer Eden Hazard had a great impact and there may be scope for him once again. Newcastle drew with Atromitos in a Europa League play-off in Greece a mere two days before this match and Alan Pardew is bound to change the lineup markedly for this match. Kevin McCarra

Defeat at Everton must be instantly answered by a win for Manchester United over Fulham, who warmed up for this visit to Old Trafford with a 5-0 defeat of Norwich City. Robin van Persie should be given his first start and the attacking pattern of United intrigues most: how Sir Alex Ferguson harnesses Shinji Kagawa, Van Persie, Wayne Rooney and Danny Welbeck will offer a first clue regarding the Scot's approach to reclaiming the title from Manchester City. October 2003 was the last time Fulham defeated United before their home crowd. Jamie Jackson

Paul Lambert's Norwich did the double in this fixture last season, but this is a very different QPR side to the one beaten at Carrow Road last November. Indeed such has been the turnover of players, only three of the Rangers first XI from that game are likely to start on Saturday. "I think we've probably allowed 20 or so players to leave. We've been able to add maybe 12 or 13 players of, in my view, better quality," said the QPR manager, Mark Hughes. Both teams are hoping to bounce back from disappointing 5-0 opening-day defeats. John Ashdown

Two clubs who came out of opening weekend meetings having avoided a battering, but not defeat, at the hands of Manchester City and Chelsea will see this game as an opportunity to get their season up and running. The Saints have lost at home only nine times in the past three league seasons – a phenomenal record – and their form at St Mary's will be key on their return to the top flight. Wigan travel to the south coast with their options trimmed, Victor Moses having yesterday finalised his transfer to Stamford Bridge. John Ashdown

Swansea eased to victory over Queens Park Rangers last Saturday with their biggest margin of victory in the top flight but West Ham will prove to be more stubborn opposition. Sam Allardyce's side had the best away record in the Championship in 2011-12 and although the 1-0 scoreline may not show it, they dominated an established Premier League side in Aston Villa last weekend. West Ham's newest signing, Matt Jarvis, is expected to go straight into the side but a knee injury will keep Jack Collison out once more, while Chico Flores and Scott Sinclair are doubts for the hosts. Ian McCourt

It feels as though there is greater interest in Tottenham's off-field machinations at present and that will increase as Friday's transfer deadline nears. There is plenty on Albion's visit, though, with André Villas-Boas admitting he needs a win, on his home debut, after the defeat at Newcastle. Up against him are Steve Clarke and Romelu Lukaku, former colleagues from his Chelsea days. Albion tails are up after the triumph over Liverpool and Villas-Boas expects them to be sharp on the counter and hard to break down. Expect a high-octane start from Tottenham. What Villas-Boas would give for an early goal. David Hytner

There was a vulnerability to the champions' defence in their opening victory over Southampton but, even including the loss of Sergio Agüero, City's start was flawless in comparison to that of Liverpool. Apprehension surrounds Brendan Rodgers's first home league game as manager following the defensive collapse at West Bromwich Albion and the loss through suspension of Daniel Agger against the club that wish to buy him. Liverpool have lost twice at home in the league to City since 1953 and must respond to the visit of a leading side to show that The Hawthorns really was just "a bad day at the office". Andy Hunter

An intriguing fixture between two clubs with a well-documented dislike for one another. Arsenal need to get their season up and running after last Saturday's goalless draw against Sunderland and it would be a huge boost to Arsène Wenger and his players if they picked up three points at the Britannia Stadium. Stoke, however, will relish the chance to make life uncomfortable for Santi Cazorla, Lukas Podolski, Olivier Giroud et al. Tony Pulis, Stoke's manager, will be forced to make at least one change, with Dean Whitehead suspended following his dismissal at Reading. Stuart James

Roberto Mancini professes himself happy with the club's summer recruitment drive so we now begin to find out if he is right. No one at the Etihad Stadium in May can forget how Manchester City beat Queens Park Rangers in the dying seconds to grab the championship as the sides reconvene for the first time since. Mancini has four from the first six points available and he will not want a stutter before the break for the World Cup qualifiers. Even Mark Hughes might be losing count of how many new players he has brought in: a draw here for his revamped band would be a fine start for them. Jamie Jackson

Michael Laudrup could hand a Premier League debut to new signing Ki Sung-yueng, but the winger Pablo Hernández was signed too late to be considered. Wayne Routledge and Chico Flores have both been troubled by minor injuries, but are expected to be passed fit for the Swans, who are aiming to continue their unbeaten start to the season. Summer signings Adam Johnson and Steven Fletcher are expected to make their first league appearances for Sunderland as the visitors look to record their first top-flight win in nine matches. Will Carpenter

Two managers at new clubs, both still seeking their first league win of the season, meet at White Hart Lane, familiar to Norwich's Chris Hughton, who spent many years there as player and coach. Moussa Dembélé, signed from Fulham to replace the transferred Luka Modric, could make his debut for André Villa-Boas's side, who are stuggling to gel under their new leader. Norwich's summer signings have not broken the bank but include the former Tottenham defender, Sebástien Bassong. Simon Lappin will miss out due to injury but his fellow midfielder Robert Snodgrass should return after a minor leg problem. Archie Smith

A meeting between two clubs that have started the Premier League season with a real flourish. Albion will be full of confidence after picking up a point at Tottenham on the back of their 3-0 win over Liverpool on the opening day, although Everton promise to provide their toughest test yet. David Moyes's side were rampant in their 3-1 triumph at Villa Park last weekend and go into this game looking to secure the win that would make it three straight league victories at the start of the season for the first time since 1993. Stuart James

Fulham will look to bounce back after a cup exit to Sheffield Wednesday and the loss of Moussa Dembélé to Tottenham. They will welcome back most of their players who were rested for the midweek game and John Arne Riise returns from injury. Dimitar Berbatov was signed too late to play, but Kieran Richardson could make his debut. For West Ham, Andy Carroll is in line to feature at some point but Jack Collison is injured and there are doubts about Winston Reid (knee), George McCartney (ankle) and James Collins (calf). Mickey McElhone

Having scored six goals in two games Wigan Athletic are looking to record their third win in as many seasons against Stoke City at the DW Stadium. Stoke are hoping their own goal tally will improve with the acquisition of Charlie Adam, who scored nine times in his first Premier League season for Blackpool. The Scot should be available having signed before midday on Friday. Despite Wigan taking three points on two occasions in the last two seasons five of the last eight top-flight meetings between the sides have been drawn. Michael Perkins

Few fixtures illustrated the importance of Robin van Persie to Arsenal last season better than their trip to Anfield, where his 93rd-minute winner sent Liverpool into the tailspin that cost Kenny Dalglish his job. A goalless start has kept the spectre of Van Persie lingering for Arsène Wenger and he faces a team that, even with transfer difficulties, has altered radically under Brendan Rodgers. The side that started and should have beaten Manchester City last week was Liverpool's youngest since December 2003 and Nuri Sahin, who nearly joined Arsenal, could make his debut on loan from Real Madrid. Andy Hunter

The Aston Villa job must have seemed a great opportunity to Paul Lambert, but for the moment it is more of a trial. Even a defeat of Tranmere in the Capital One Cup would have been appreciated following the loss of both Premier League fixtures to date. Newcastle, however, will see this as another chance to confirm they are a club on the rise. The hosts' full-back Ryan Taylor could be out for up to six months after sustaining a knee injury in the 1-0 Europa League victory over Atromitos on Thursday night. Kevin McCarra

Southampton have lost both their matches since returning to the Premier League and face another difficult assignment, even if Manchester United are still troubled by various injury issues. Sir Alex Ferguson's side have looked vulnerable at times in defence during their opening two games, which should at least give the home side some encouragement after last week's defeat to Wigan Athletic. Gastón Ramírez was not signed in time to figure but Emmanuel Mayuka, the new Zambian striker, stands by to make his debut at some point. Daniel Taylor

Olivier Giroud confessed to freezing in front of goal so far, but the omens are good for him to warm up against this opponent. It was against Southampton that Ian Wright, Dennis Bergkamp and Thierry Henry scored their first Premier League goals for Arsenal. Keeping a handle on Santi Cazorla is key for Saints, whose lively play over an unkind set of opening fixtures has been impressive. The four goals scored by Saturday's visitors against the two Manchester teams are not to be sniffed at. Newly resilient Arsenal must not be complacent. Amy Lawrence

Two clubs with new managers that have made contrasting starts to the season. Swansea are flying high in second place, with two wins and a draw, while Aston Villa picked up their one and only point, against Newcastle, last time out. Paul Lambert must decide whether to field any of his four new signings and he also has the option of bringing Gabriel Agbonlahor into the starting lineup. Swansea are forced to reshuffle at the back – Neil Taylor is out for the remainder of the season while Chico Flores starts a three-match ban. Stuart James

Given that Steve Clarke has been a No2 at Chelsea and Liverpool, the top four is not unfamiliar territory for him but it is to Albion fans who, even at this early stage of the season, are wide-eyed in disbelief at being in third place. Victory in this fixture for the first time in 45 years could even see them go top on Saturday. Martin Jol, having lost the services of Moussa Dembélé and Clint Dempsey across the capital to Tottenham, gives a first start to Dimitar Berbatov, who will need him to find his old Spurs form if Fulham are to prosper. Paul Chronnell

After the international break, Sir Alex Ferguson surveys a squad still hobbled by a lack of defensive cover owing to Phil Jones' new knee injury and Chris Smalling's ongoing recovery from a metatarsal fracture, while Wayne Rooney's gashed leg sees him at least fortnight away from a return. United also have three points to make up on Chelsea, the early leaders, but against a club routed 5-0 in last season's corresponding fixture, confidence should be high. Roberto Martínez, though, will remind his players of their 1-0 win over United in April's reverse game which dented title hopes. Jamie Jackson

Norwich's manager, Chris Hughton, has denied his team are a soft touch despite them not receiving a yellow card in their first three games. Sam Allardyce's West Ham, conversely, have already picked up four cautions and are renowned for adopting a no-nonsense approach. While their physical threat will be somewhat lessened by the absence of the on-loan Liverpool striker Andy Carroll with a hamstring injury, the Hammers will still present an imposing challenge for a Norwich side who have yet to get going in 2012-13. Rich Flower

The focus at Loftus Road will initially be drawn, albeit with a weary sense of dread, to the pre-match handshake, though it is the football that should prove compelling. QPR's start to the new campaign may have been haphazard at best but there is quality in the squad Mark Hughes has thrown together at lavish expense and, if the home side can gel in the frenzied atmosphere, they should test Chelsea's perfect start to the Premier League season. Aside from the John Terry furore, last season's corresponding fixture was spiky, with the visitors reduced to nine men, beaten, and their confidence shaken for the weeks ahead. Roberto Di Matteo will be desperate to avoid a repeat. Dominic Fifield

Michael Owen, brought in from the wilderness and trying to restore his reputation as an accomplished goalscorer, has declared himself fit to make his debut for Stoke City, almost two years since his last league start with Manchester United. Tony Pulis, the Stoke manager, may give a debut to Steven Nzonzi and Charlie Adam is in line for his first start. City, too, have new players available : Maicon, Matija Nastasic, Javi García and Scott Sinclair. Most importantly, perhaps, they could also have Sergio Agüero available again after his knee injury. Daniel Taylor

At the end of a week in which the prime minister has apologised to Liverpool fans for terrible wrongs that took place 23 years ago at Hillsborough, the atmosphere on Wearside promises to be poignant and evocative. "It will be highly charged because of what happened on Wednesday," said the Sunderland manager, Martin O'Neill. "It will be a very emotional occasion with Liverpool fans coming in their droves." While Brendan Rodgers's players aim to begin correcting a disappointing start to the campaign, Sunderland have surmounted problems with their new pitch's drainage and finally play their first home league game of the season. Louise Taylor

It is far too early for rampaging anxiety, but André Villas-Boas must surely be eager for a first victory with Tottenham in the Premier League. Although a match at newly promoted Reading will seem promising, the hosts have the benefit of continuity – the manager, Brian McDermott, has served the club in one post or another for 12 years. Like Villas-Boas, he is in search of a first league win in this campaign, but McDermott does not have to cope with the same level of expectation. Jimmy Kébé may return after missing the start of the season with a hamstring injury. Kevin McCarra

Everton host Newcastle on the back of three wins from four in all competitions after an uncharacteristically good start to the new season. But with the home side's loss of Darron Gibson with a thigh strain, and coming off the back of a 2-1 defeat at West Bromwich Albion, they have a tough task in halting a potent Newcastle attack; Hatem Ben Arfa will be looking to recreate his wonder strike against Aston Villa a fortnight ago. Perhaps the most glaring omission for the visitors is that of Tim Krul – the Dutch goalkeeper picked up an elbow injury on Holland duty. Mike Butcher

Having grabbed headlines in midweek with an impressive double, Chelsea will have to assess the fitness of the Brazil playmaker Oscar, who will now be eager to make his mark in the Premier League. Both teams head into this contest unbeaten, but Tony Pulis will be looking to end a woeful run of form travelling to the new "big four" – Stoke have lost their previous 16 matches at Manchester United, Manchester City, Arsenal and Chelsea. Michael Owen will hope for a first league start after a brief substitute cameo last weekend but Andy Wilkinson starts a three-match ban following his clash with Mario Balotelli. Roberto Di Matteo will be desperate to put last week's handshake feud behind him as Chelsea strive to consolidate their lead at the top of the Premier League table. Xander Drury

Bottom-of-the-table Southampton aim to get off the mark after a tough opening which included admirable efforts in 3-2 defeats by both Manchester clubs. Record signing Gastón Ramírez is in line for his full debut after coming off the bench against Arsenal last week and Nigel Adkins may also contemplate dropping Jos Hooiveld, who is struggling with a calf problem and has made several costly errors recently. The hosts' porous defence could be tested by Christian Benteke, who scored the second in Aston Villa's win over Swansea, and Darren Bent, looking for his first Premier League goal since February. Ron Vlaar should continue to captain the side after taking on the role in Villa's last game. Sean Cole

Swansea hope to recover at home to a wounded Everton side who felt they deserved all three points after some controversial decisions in the 2-2 draw with Newcastle. Michael Laudrup has something of a defensive crisis to deal with: Chico Flores is still suspended, Neil Taylor out for the season, and now the captain, Ashley Williams, faces a late fitness test. For the away side, Everton will be without last season's leading scorer, Nikica Jelavic, who limped out of Monday's match. Goalscoring substitute Victor Anichebe is in the frame to deputise. Sean Cole

After Peter Odemwingie's moment of madness, the Nigerian receiving a red card for kicking out at Fulham's Sascha Riether last week, he begins a three-match ban. Chelsea loanee Romelu Lukaku, with a goal to his name already against Liverpool, will look to fill in, but the more versatile Marc-Antoine Fortuné may be preferred. Having replaced Adam Federici in goal for the visit of Tottenham, Alex McCarthy's solid display, despite the scoreline, should be enough to secure his place. The visitors go into this game winless from three attempts. Sean Cole

How things have changed since these two teams last met. Different managers, new personnel and fresh chances. With three draws thus far, Sunderland demonstrated their tenacity and organisation last week to steal a point against a dominant Liverpool, but Martin O'Neill will still be worried by an 11-match winless run, stretching back to May. In contrast, West Ham can boast a 100 per cent home record this season, with Jussi Jaaskelainen – secured on a free transfer at the tender age of 37 – yet to concede at Upton Park. The visitors will most likely be without the England winger Adam Johnson, who has a thigh injury, whilst the hosts will continue to employ Carlton Cole and possibly Modibo Maïga as well in the absence of Andy Carroll, who returned to light training this week. Xander Drury

Wigan, with four points from four games, will be pleased to be back at the DW Stadium after a 4-0 savaging at Old Trafford. They hope to have Antolín Alcaraz resuming defensive duties alongside Gary Caldwell and Iván Ramis, with Emmerson Boyce dropping to the bench. After two classy goals on his home debut, Dimitar Berbatov will lead the line once more for Fulham. In support of him, Hugo Rodallega will hope for a chance to face his former club but Mladen Petric and Bryan Ruiz are back in contention after overcoming niggles. Midfielder Mahamadou Diarra could be out for the season depending on the severity of his knee injury. Sean Cole

Anfield's tribute to the victims of Hillsborough and their families' 23-year fight to expose an establishment cover-up demands the focus ahead of Sunday. But there is no denying the significance of what follows to Liverpool and their manager. Brendan Rodgers has yet to win a Premier League game since his switch from Swansea and, for all the signs of improvement, will be hoping United's appearance at Anfield galvanises Liverpool once again. Sir Alex Ferguson fielded a strong side in Europe in midweek, Rodgers rested his senior players, and United are seeking a first league win at Anfield since December 2007. Andy Hunter

It is particularly bemusing to see a role reversal for these clubs. Unbeaten Arsenal have conceded just two goals in the five fixtures completed in Premier League and Champions League. It is not so very long since Roberto Mancini's Manchester City were viewed as the austere club, but there has not been a clean sheet so far this season and a 2-1 lead against Real Madrid with five minutes left at the Bernabéu still ended in a 3-2 loss. Mancini would surely be relieved to see a painstaking win over Arsène Wenger's team. Kevin McCarra

Chris Hughton can expect a deservedly warm welcome on his return to the club he led out of the Championship. While the popular Hughton hopes to guide Norwich to a first league win of the season, his successor on Tyneside contemplates assorted dilemmas. With Tim Krul injured should Alan Pardew select Rob Elliot in goal ahead of Steve Harper? Should he field the unsettled Demba Ba in his preferred central attacking role or on the left of the 4-3-3 formation which probably suits Newcastle best? And should he find a starting slot for the promising young midfielder Gaël Bigirimana? Louise Taylor

André Villas-Boas can breath a sigh of relief as the cloud hanging over White Hart Lane begins to lift. With an emphatic 3-1 victory over Reading last Sunday and a well-earned draw against Lazio on Thursday, Tottenham have certainly allayed some of the fears building in north London. Villas-Boas faces a goalkeeping dilemma, but is expected to retain Brad Friedel ahead of the £12m summer signing, Hugo Lloris, who made his debut against Lazio, who was granted his first start this week. Languishing in the relegation zone, QPR's new-look team are still seeking their first league win with Anton Ferdinand and Fábio da Silva both ruled out for two weeks. But after a hard-fought draw against Chelsea last week, it would be churlish to dismiss Mark Hughes' chances of grabbing an upset. Xander Drury

Chelsea may have won all three of their Premier League crowns since Arsenal last achieved the feat in 2004, but whether the strongest title challenge comes from west or north London this season is up for debate. Neither club have yet tasted defeat, and while Roberto Di Matteo's side are the early frontrunners, this game represents the first genuine test of their new-look style. With Santi Cazorla having adapted instantly to English football to become Arsenal's creative hub, Arsène Wenger's side look similarly regenerated. Paul Chronnell Emirates Stadium, Saturday 12.45pm

Everton could go top with a home win and favourable results elsewhere. "Psychologically it would be a big thing for the club and supporters," said David Moyes. They certainly need a response to the dreadful display that contributed to the League Cup exit at Leeds United in midweek to maintain the early-season optimism around Goodison Park. Southampton, inspired on and off the pitch by two Liverpool fans, manager Nigel Adkins and striker Rickie Lambert, will be buoyed by their overdue first win of the season last week and new signing Artur Boruc could make his debut in goal. Andy Hunter

Manchester City's has been a stodgy start to the season, their unbeaten league record rather deceptive with too many draws and far too many goals shipped en route. Roberto Mancini's side arrive at Craven Cottage, where they dropped their first points last term, without a clean sheet and feeling vulnerable. Fulham have won this fixture only once since these teams met in the third tier back in 1998, but they have rallied in recent weeks. Dimitar Berbatov's absence is a considerable blow, but both their home games have been won emphatically. They can test City's fragile form. Dominic Fifield

Since Manchester United lost 1-0 at Everton in their season opener Sir Alex Ferguson has set the controls to 'victory', with his side reeling off six consecutive wins. Nemanja Vidic's knee injury means Ferguson is down to his last two senior centre-backs in Jonny Evans and Rio Ferdinand, and with the latter's need to manage a back condition, André Villas-Boas will ask his resurgent Tottenham side to drive at the home defence. If successful Spurs could finally secure a first league win at Old Trafford since 1989. Jamie Jackson

After a disappointing defeat to Manchester United at Anfield last weekend, Liverpool are still looking for their first victory of the league season, although the midweek Capital One Cup win over West Bromwich Albion will have gone some way to lifting the cloud over the manager Brendan Rodgers. Norwich, also winless, have drawn both of their home games against West Ham United and QPR but have managed just the single goal. Grant Holt is still looking for his first goal and a semblance of last season's form. Andrew Lawton

"I loved the performance against QPR," the Reading manager Brian McDermott said following their Capital One cup win on Wednesday. McDermott described the win as a "great lift," saying "we needed that". Reading sit bottom, but victory could lift them out of the relegation zone. For Newcastle, whose striker Papiss Cissé broke a 10-game scoring drought at Old Trafford in the week, three points at the Madjeski Stadium would be their first away win and provide much needed strength to their European hopes. Andrew Lawton

Swansea is a rugby city but it must have jarred to see the football club's urbane manager, Michael Laudrup, leading a training session that used tackle bags to recreate the goalmouth scrum he expects to face at Stoke on Saturday. "It's good preparation for matches like this," said Swansea's goalkeeper, Michael Vorm. "I'm not afraid of anyone. You have to make sure you come and fight." Stoke's manager Tony Pulis usually bites back at implied criticism but with his side's home form in disarray, he has more pressing issues to address. James Callow

Wigan are spared the bruising prospect of facing their former midfielder Lee Cattermole as Sunderland's captain is suspended once again. Martin O'Neill hopes Adam Johnson will be fit in time to try and help his side secure their first Premier League win since March. The former Manchester City winger has made one league appearance since arriving on Wearside last month and O'Neill is suitably frustrated. "It's touch and go for Adam," he said. "But I wouldn't want to continue too much longer without his knack of unlocking defences." Louise Taylor

This is a difficult derby to call. Albion have made a superb start to the Premier League season while Villa have only four points on the board and were thumped at Southampton last Saturday. Paul Lambert, however, claimed that "confidence is sky-high" among his Villa players after their surprise win at Manchester City in the League Cup in midweek. Gabriel Agbonlahor scored two in that game, which leaves Lambert with a selection dilemma up front. Albion's main worry concerns the fitness of the former Villa player Liam Ridgewell. Stuart James

Sam Allardyce, the West Ham manager, described his sides defending as "comical" after their 4-1 defeat to Wigan in the Capital One Cup. The dire performance led to Allardyce claiming his players were "putting their West Ham careers in jeopardy" despite being unbeaten in the league in September. Winless QPR are yet to find the net at Loftus Road and goals are becoming a real problem. Bobby Zamora remains their only league goalscorer but the assistant manager Mark Bowen is "very hopeful" of a return for Adel Taarabt. Andrew Lawton

If Chelsea are hoping for a comfortable outing following their midweek Champions League exertions and ahead of upcoming fixtures against Tottenham, Shaktar Donestsk and Manchester United, twice, they are likely to be disappointed as Norwich will be hell bent on improving on last week's sorry showing against Liverpool, when they were defeated 5-2 at home. Chelsea should still have enough to prevail, but Roberto Di Matteo, their manager, may not be able to rest as many players as he might like to. Paul Doyle

In search of a positive message to give his beleaguered side, Roberto Mancini can remind them that Manchester City are still unbeaten in the league after six games ahead of welcoming Sunderland to the Etihad Stadium. The problem is a porous defence that has allowed 16 goals in all competitions, the weakness Martin O'Neill will encourage his side to focus on. Last season Sunderland took four points from City, so Mancini will hardly relish taking them on as his men try to claw back Chelsea's early-season lead. Jamie Jackson

This is the first meeting between these teams since Swansea won a barnstorming Championship play-off final in May 2011. That match ended 4-2 and do not bet against more goals in this one, with both teams having displayed defensive frailties this season. Reading are still to record a league win but are near full-strength, with only the goalkeeper Adam Federici ruled out, although Mikele Leigertwood may miss the game with a dead leg. For Swansea, Ashley Williams faces a fitness test on an ankle. Tom Lutz

With QPR propping up the table, the pressure is building on Mark Hughes. Tony Fernandes, the Rangers chairman, has shown his support for the manager but frustration is growing among the supporters ahead of what promises to be another tough game for a team that has failed to win away in the league since November. Albion have picked up maximum points at The Hawthorns this season and not conceded a goal in the process. They have Peter Odemwingie back from suspension while Samba Diakité serves a one-match ban for QPR. Stuart James

This is West Ham's most demanding challenge since their return to the Premier League, and one they will relish. Relatively kind opening fixtures have allowed them to settle back in to the top flight impressively, but Arsenal have the guile to ask them questions. The visitors are, though, slightly pressurised after losing some confidence and fluency in defeat to Chelsea. Per Mertesacker's return would be welcome to shore up a defence that has looked vulnerable in his absence, particularly if Andy Carroll is in the mood to cause some damage. Amy Lawrence

Historically, both teams find their form later in the season. As usual Wigan have started slowly – four points from six games is the club's worst ever start to a Premier League campaign – but Everton sit second in the Premier League with reasonable fixtures to come. David Moyes will be without Tony Hibbert (calf) and Darron Gibson (thigh), while Wigan can field Jordi Gómez after his red card against Sunderland was rescinded. If Kevin Mirallas can continue his excellent form, Wigan could be in for a very long afternoon. Tom Lutz

There will be contrasting styles on show but a change in results at Anfield has to be the priority for Brendan Rodgers. For all the appreciation of how he is trying to evolve Liverpool the fact remains Rodgers' team have lost their last three games at home. Tony Pulis may claim to be aggrieved at Peter Crouch's omission from the latest England squad but with the former Liverpool striker "on fire", and Michael Owen available to face his former club, Stoke have the means to test an unconvincing home defence. Andy Hunter

Newcastle United won 3-0 against Manchester United in January. The margin of victory was a surprise and this is usually a full-blooded fixture. Newcastle's firepower has not been all that intense of late so the 3-0 defeat of Bordeaux in their Europa League group tie on Thursday evening must have felt timely. All the same, Sir Alex Ferguson's team ought to present far more of a test. They have won their three away matches in all competitions since the 1-0 defeat at Everton in the opening round of fixtures. Kevin McCarra

Southampton's league fixtures have been a treat for neutrals so far this season, producing nearly five goals a game. Unfortunately for Saints fans, most of those goals have been conceded by their team. Going into this match, only the injured Jack Cork is unavailable for the hosts, while Jos Hooiveld is back to strengthen their leaky defence. Fulham are likely to once again be without Dimitar Berbatov but Kerim Frei, Philippe Senderos and Simon Davies could all return to Martin Jol's squad for their trip to the south coast. Tom Lutz

Darren Bent's finishing skills were once compared unfavourably to those of Harry Redknapp's wife by the former Tottenham manager and, as a result, the striker tends not to want for motivation when he faces his old club at White Hart Lane. Bent is bristling with it at present, after being dropped last weekend against West Bromwich Albion only to come on and score the equaliser. Which Aston Villa will turn up? Inconsistency has devilled them. Tottenham, by contrast, are picking up under André Villas-Boas and they are chasing their fourth league win in a row. David Hytner

Despite Fulham finishing 14 points and seven places above Villa last season, the two clubs started the season with their usual differing expectations. Paul Lambert was handed the Villa Park reins and charged with rekindling glory days that are now more than 30 years ago, while Martin Jol knows maintaining mid-table mediocrity will keep his employers and supporters happy. Jol welcomes back both Dimitar Berbatov and Mladen Petric who will aim to expose a Villa rearguard sorely missing the presence of Richard Dunne. Paul Chronnell

The patience that Brendan Rodgers was denied at Reading has been plentiful throughout a difficult start at Anfield but it is not an endless supply, and a first home league win as Liverpool manager is long overdue with the nights closing in. Injury to Fabio Borini is the latest problem to befall Rodgers and leaves Luis Suárez, who has seven goals in seven games in all competitions, as his only fit senior striker. Brian McDermott is seeking his first league win of the season at the expense of a close friend, the two managers having worked together for 10 years in Reading's youth system. Andy Hunter

Considering that England's match in Poland had to be put back a day, Sir Alex Ferguson must regret the reduction in recovery time for Michael Carrick, Tom Cleverley and Wayne Rooney, who all started in Warsaw. Still, the sympathy will lie far more with the visitors to Old Trafford, Stoke City. They last took a point there in December 1980, with a 2-2 draw after going 2-0 up in the first 21 minutes. Stoke have just one win in this campaign, against Swansea, but Tony Pulis's team went on to take a goalless draw at Anfield last time out. Kevin McCarra

Given his Tottenham connections, Chris Hughton would like nothing more than overseeing a defeat of Arsenal, but should that occur the Norwich manager's principal emotion is likely to be relief rather than joy given his side sit in the relegation zone having lost their last three games and having failed to win any in the league all season. Arsenal are formidable opponents, but Norwich can take hope from their lengthy injury list, which includes, among others, Theo Walcott, Kieran Gibbs, Wojciech Szczesny and Lukasz Fabianski. Sachin Nakrani

Two sides with a similarly expansive style, and a similarly inconsistent beginning to the season meet at the Liberty Stadium. Michael Laudrup's side have come through the international break unscathed, and welcome back Kemy Agustien after a calf injury, but Roberto Martínez returns to Swansea with doubts over the match fitness of both Maynor Figueroa and Jean Beausejour after long journeys back from representing Honduras and Chile in World Cup qualifiers. Plus, Antolín Alcaraz and Albert Crusat are both definitely unavailable for the visitors Toby Moses

It is often forgotten that André Villas-Boas made a pretty positive start to his managerial tenure at Chelsea last season. Before the QPR defeat that changed everything, his Premier League record read: W6 D1 L1. Things were also going well in the Champions League. His numbers back then compare favourably to his opening at Tottenham, where he is credited with laying encouraging foundations. Stability and consistency, he acknowledges, came to elude him at Chelsea and he is obsessed with finding those qualities now. This derby against his former assistant Roberto Di Matteo feels like a defining moment. David Hytner

This promises to be an awkward fixture for City. Albion are only a point behind the champions after winning their opening four homes games in the top flight for the first time since 1919. Make it five in a row and Albion fans will start to believe something special can be achieved this season. City will be without the injured quartet of David Silva, Jack Rodwell, Maicon and Javi García against a side that Roberto Mancini rates highly. "In this moment, I think West Bromwich is the team that has played the best football," he said. Stuart James

These sides met in the Championship last season but it is West Ham, rather than automatically-promoted Southampton, who have started the Premier League campaign with more authority. If the Saints are to come away from Upton Park with a positive result then they will have to improve their abysmal defensive record which stands at 20 goals conceded in seven matches. Andy Carroll should start and will hope to capitalise on that frailty, while Southampton will be without their injured record signing Gastón Ramírez. James Riach

Two managers at opposite ends of the spectrum meet at Loftus Road – QPR's Mark Hughes is the even-money favourite to be the next Premier League manager to leave his post, while bookmakers reckon only Sir Alex Ferguson is safer than Everton's David Moyes. Three successive defeats have put Hughes on the ropes, his team are without a win this season, and his cause won't be helped by lingering injuries in defence. Everton will hope to give a debut to Thomas Hitzlsperger, who signed on a free transfer on Friday. John Ashdown

Let's hope everyone behaves better than during the last derby at St James' Park. That 1-1 draw in March featured two red cards, eight yellows and an unedifying managerial slanging match on the touchline. Afterwards Martin O'Neill refused Alan Pardew's offer of a drink and the pair did not make up until May. With Lee Cattermole suspended there will be no renewal of the Sunderland captain's ferocious rivalry with Cheik Tioté but plenty of fascinating sub-plots remain. Can Davide Santon subdue Adam Johnson? Will Steven Fletcher extend his extraordinary scoring streak after drawing a blank against Manchester City? Can Sunderland contain Hatem Ben Arfa? Louise Taylor

An unhappy week for Arsène Wenger, marked by defeats away at Norwich and at home to Schalke, and seasoned by a difficult club AGM. On the face of it, QPR look like ideal convalescent opposition: bottom of the league, with a manager under pressure, and unsettled both by recent team-building efforts and the unresolved background chunter of Anton Ferdinand's involvement in the John Terry affair. On the other hand, they are something of a bogey team, statistically Arsenal's least favoured opponents in the Premier League alongside Manchester United. Wenger could give Jack Wilshere his first top-flight appearance in 18 months and Bacary Sagna may also be back in the squad. Barney Ronay

Paul Lambert insists this fixture is "just another game" and Chris Hughton says the history between his opposite number and Norwich "is a very small detail", but it is fair to say that Canaries supporters do not share that view. The Aston Villa manager's acrimonious departure from Carrow Road means those rising early to make the trip from Norfolk to the Midlands will be eagerly anticipating a modicum of revenge. Villa's patchy form and Norwich's morale boosting win over Arsenal last week mean they will be confident of getting it. John Ashdown

Roberto Mancini has come in for some heavy criticism this week after Manchester City were soundly beaten by Ajax in the Champions League on Wednesday night. City's injuries and suspensions will leave Michael Laudrup and his Swansea team believing they have a real chance at taking something from the champions. Both teams won on their last outing in the Premier League, Swansea beating Wigan 2-1 at the Liberty Stadium and City defeating West Bromwich Albion by the same scoreline thanks to an injury time winner from Edin Dzeko. Mark Proctor

Jason Roberts' refusal to wear a Kick It Out T-shirt on another day of action for the anti-racism group will grab the attention ahead of this match but Reading's focus is squarely on securing their first Premier League win of the season. Brian McDermott has spoken confidently about his team's chances of climbing out of the relegation zone but he is likely to be concerned about the threat posed by Fulham, the division's fourth highest scorers. Pavel Pogrebnyak, facing his old side, could be a key figure for Reading. Sachin Nakrani

The battle of the red-and-white stripes could see Glenn Whelan make his return for Stoke – the midfielder returned to training on Thursday following a hamstring problem – while Lee Cattermole is available again for Sunderland following a three-match suspension. Martin O'Neill has been open about his respect for the hosts. "Stoke have had a fantastic time over the last few years – ever since they won promotion," he said. "The manager has done a fantastic job there and has a great relationship with his chairman." Kathleen Hawkins

The Wigan trio of Ryo Miyaichi, Antolín Alcaraz and Albert Crusat are all struggling with injuries and look unlikely to feature on Saturday. This could be good for the visitors – who have had their best start in 13 years – and whose away form is looking impressive, with three victories and one loss in their last six matches. Wigan, on the other hand, are dangerously close to the relegation zone and West Ham supporters will want to eradicate memories of two seasons ago when Charles N'Zogbia's last-minute goal dramatically secured the Hammers' relegation. Kathleen Hawkins

This will be the 50th time Sir Alex Ferguson has taken his Manchester United side into a top-flight game against Chelsea. His record so far stands at 16 wins, 18 draws and 15 defeats, with only six victories from 25 trips to Stamford Bridge. That is fairly modest by Ferguson's standards and this promises to be another difficult assignment judging by the fact Roberto Di Matteo's team have dropped only two points so far. Chelsea will be without the injured Frank Lampard and the suspended John Terry but that is not as big a problem for the hosts as it once was. As for the inevitable scrutiny on the pre-match handshakes, Rio Ferdinand and Ashley Cole are both coming round to the idea it would be a good thing to acknowledge one another. Daniel Taylor

Everton have been the stronger, better balanced team on Merseyside this season – just as they were before losing three times to Liverpool last term – but less convincing in their last two outings and are without the suspended Steven Pienaar. His loss may be felt against a Liverpool team who have kept three successive clean sheets and won nine of the last 12 league meetings at Goodison Park. Brendan Rodgers must hope there are no tired limbs for his first Merseyside derby as Liverpool manager following his strong team selection in the Europa League on Thursday. Andy Hunter

Considering that John Carver, Alan Pardew's assistant, is a good friend of Albion's Steve Clarke and Kevin Keen, Clarke's deputy, previously filled the same role under Pardew at West Ham it will be a case of friends reunited on Tyneside. Stretched by Europa League involvement, Newcastle have six points fewer than at this stage last season and could do with a win if they are to continue harbouring hopes of Champions League qualification. Much may depend on how young Gaël Bigirimana copes as a deputy for the suspended Cheik Tiote in the home side's midfield. Louise Taylor

A win for Southampton against Tottenham on Sunday could be enough to take them out of the bottom three if results elsewhere go their way. Spurs have been beaten in their last five Premier League visits to Southampton, and to add to that, they did not manage to score in any of them. But going from current form, they look like favourites. Saints have won just once this season, while Spurs have four victories. Expect goals as Southampton have the leakiest defence in the top flight, conceding 24 goals in only eight matches. Mark Proctor

David Moyes considers Fulham to be a team who will push for a Europa League place and a win would see them leapfrog Everton, who have drawn their last three. "If we are going to hang on to the coat-tails of teams above us we are going to have to keep winning and playing well," said the Everton manager, who has Steven Pienaar back after a ban and is hopeful Kevin Mirallas will make it after limping off in the derby. Dimitar Berbatov's rib is a concern for Fulham, although he had a jab in the draw at Reading and got on with it. Mark Tallentire

After the 7-5 comes memories of the 8-2 for Arsenal. Arsène Wenger's men travel to Old Trafford buoyed by their incredible midweek recovery against Reading and looking to avenge the mauling they suffered away to Manchester United last season. This is undoubtedly a stronger Arsenal side but there has been one significant weakness to their ranks since that defeat – the loss of Robin van Persie, who has continued to sparkle since joining United in August and on Saturday lunchtime has the chance to harm former team-mates. Sachin Nakrani

Norwich will be buoyed after their midweek win over Tottenham in the Capital One Cup, giving them their first cup quarter-final appearance for 18 years. The Canaries have only won one Premier League game this season, but given that victory came against Arsenal they will feel confident of also overcoming Stoke. The visitors won the last time these sides met in the league thanks to a late strike from Matthew Etherington. Tony Pulis will see this as a chance for his side to secure their first away win of the season. Amy Lofthouse

Might Paul Lambert recall Sunderland old boy Darren Bent? Will a home player other than Steven Fletcher manage to score a goal for Martin O'Neill's shot-shy side? How will the Stadium of Light react if Sunderland compound their midweek cup exit to Middlesbrough by slipping up again in the Premier League? Lambert played for O'Neill at Celtic and was later recommended for the Wycombe job by the Northern Irishman, but the pair's mutual admiration will be placed on hold as they strive to keep the critics at bay by overcoming underwhelming starts to the season. Louise Taylor

Swansea's Capital One Cup victory over Liverpool will have given Michael Laudrup's players great encouragement after an inconsistent start to the season. These two sides previously met in January, where a late own goal from Neil Taylor denied Swansea a victory over Chelsea, and, this time around, the visitors will be looking to put their latest controversy behind them and consolidate their position at the top of the table. Roberto Di Matteo's men, having not lost an away league game this season, should triumph. Amy Lofthouse

Both of these sides suffered Capital One Cup eliminations during the week, with Wigan's defeat by Bradford more alarming than Tottenham's loss at Norwich, although that defeat did highlight a problem that must bother André Villas-Boas. Spurs are still not scoring as many goals as they should be, with the top scorer Jermain Defoe still guilty of missing many chances, Emmanuel Adebayor out of favour and Clint Dempsey not yet fitting in. Gareth Bale and Aaron Lennon can be counted on to continue creating chances but hope for Wigan comes from the fact that Spurs are not sure to take them. Paul Doyle

This trip to London might feel like an inconvenience to Manchester City given the do-or-die nature of the Champions League assignment against Ajax, but Roberto Mancini will stress the need to retain focus in the Premier League, where the club remain unbeaten despite rarely hitting the heights of last season. Leading players have yet to get going and Mancini has issues to vex him, not least the manner in which opposing teams are raising themselves against the champions. West Ham represent the latest awkward test. David Hytner

Brendan Rodgers lamented Liverpool's continued reliance on Steven Gerrard, plus Luis Suárez, after the Capital One Cup defeat by Swansea, but he was not the first Anfield manager to do so. Gerrard will become the 10th player in Liverpool's history to make 600 appearances for the club on Sunday and needs victory not to record the milestone but to ignite the season. As do Newcastle, who have yet to win away from home so far this campaign. Liverpool have not won back-to-back league games at home since September 2011.Suárez and Demba Ba are both in the form to maintain the fixture's high-scoring traditions. Andy Hunter

Tension is unavoidable as the Premier League's two win-less teams meet for the first time in the top flight. The pressure on Mark Hughes's team is a little warmer given the money he spent on fresh ammunition over the summer. Queens Park Rangers could do with keeping all 11 players on the pitch, and they have not won a game this term when they have conceded the first goal (six times). Reading played with admirable heart against Fulham last weekend, but it remains to be seen how they react to the shock of blowing a 4-0 lead in midweek. Amy Lawrence

West Bromwich's impressive start to the season has seen Steve Clarke build on the foundations left by Roy Hodgson and despite last month's 2-1 loss to Manchester City, Albion have proved they can handle themselves and, as such, will be confident of overcoming a Southampton side one place off the bottom of the table. Saints have only one win to their name since returning to the top flight and suffered a Capital One Cup defeat at Leeds in midweek when, once again, their defence was very shaky under pressure. Amy Lofthouse

Arsenal have found Fulham awkward customers to deal with over the last couple of seasons. Indeed, it is almost two years since the Gunners were victorious against their neighbours on the other side of the capital, with the Cottagers unbeaten in their last three Premier League fixtures against Arsène Wenger's side. "There's no pressure on us, it's all on Arsenal," said Fulham's Chris Baird. "We can go there, try and play our football and see what happens." Martin Jol will be hoping Kieran Richardson shakes off a bout of illness in time to feature. John Ashdown

Since a 3-1 victory over Sir Alex Ferguson's kids 17 years ago, Villa have crumbled when United visit. Paul Lambert's revolution is making slow but steady progress, his young side's three-match unbeaten run putting a relatively comfortable four-point buffer between themselves and the relegation zone. Villa are boosted by the return after suspension of Karim El Ahmadi, whose crisp passing has brought some vital composure to an otherwise inexperienced midfield; Villa have held the majority of possession on only two occasions this season. The hosts will need significantly higher ball retention than in recent weeks if they are to stunt a visiting side that seem to be steadily growing in confidence as the season progresses. United have won four successive league games since the shock 3-2 defeat by Tottenham, and with a relatively straight forward run of games until the Manchester derby in early December, Ferguson will be keen to ensure his team do not drop points against sides as depleted as Villa. Alex Keble

Four successive draws have put the brakes on Everton's uncharacteristically rip-roaring start to the season, and with Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester City on the fixture list between now and Christmas, David Moyes's side could do with getting back to winning ways. With struggling Sunderland, with one goal and no wins in their last five games, visiting Goodison Park, they could hardly wish for a better opportunity. Martin O'Neill's verdict that his side are playing "reasonably OK" was hardly a ringing endorsement. John Ashdown

"For us, there are no easy matches – irrespective of the opposition, we have to be on top of our game," said the Norwich manager, Chris Hughton, ahead of his side's trip to 18th-placed Reading. The Royals manager, Brian McDermott, insisted this week that "every single person at the club is going in the same direction" and there does seem to be plenty of positivity at the Madejski, despite the club still being in search of their first league win. "The win is coming, everyone knows it," said the Reading midfielder Jem Karacan. John Ashdown

Southampton are in desperate need of a win to ease some of the pressure on Nigel Adkins, and the visit of Swansea presents a good opportunity to collect three points for only the second time this season. The Saints manager has denied reports he was issued with an ultimatum this week by the chairman but a fifth successive defeat in all competitions would still be disastrous. Michael Laudrup has told his players to be wary of a motivated side keen to save their manager, although he will be quietly confident of a good performance following his team's impressive 1-1 draw against Chelsea last weekend. Jack Cork should be fit to make his first appearance of the season, and Southampton fans can welcome the record signing Gastón Ramírez to St Mary's after he returned from injury to face West Bromwich Albion on Monday. Five of Southampton's next seven fixtures are at home, the highest placed of these opponents being Newcastle in 10th. Southampton's fate will most likely be decided over the next few weeks; a win on Saturday would be the perfect way to kickstart their season. Alex Keble

Tony Pulis could be forgiven for feeling pretty grateful to Mark Hughes. QPR's winless campaign, coupled with the struggles of Southampton and Reading, have meant that Stoke's own slow start has gone largely unnoticed. Pulis's Potters have won only one in 10 thus far and have scored six goals fewer than rock-bottom Southampton. "The disappointing thing is we've players who have goals in them," said Pulis. "The one thing I didn't think we'd have a problem with this season is scoring goals. But things like this happen so you have to make sure everybody stays nice and calm, keeps the belief, keeps the faith." Archie Smith

Albion's Steve Clarke has been making an early bid for manager of the season, but he is determined to keep his feet on the ground. "People ask about Europe but it is too early for that," he said. "It is a dangerous league. If we hadn't won the other night against Southampton, we would be stuck in mid-table." Wigan are looking to complete a hat-trick of wins, after victories against West Ham and, particularly impressively, at Tottenham last weekend. But Roberto Martínez also struck a cautious note, describing this fixture as "arguably one of the toughest this season". Archie Smith

This is a fixture that tends to coax the best out of the visitors. Kenny Dalglish's side prevailed twice at Stamford Bridge within a matter of weeks last term, undermining André Villas-Boas's position in the process, and Brendan Rodgers will urge them to prove their current position is deceptive. Roberto Di Matteo, a manager overseeing a team brimming with attacking verve, will seek evidence of some solidity of old and may restore John Terry, on his return from domestic suspension, to confront the slippery Luis Suárez. The hosts could start the day four points off the top. This is no occasion to slip up. Dominic Fifield

Sunday's visit of Tottenham presents a side that has already beaten Manchester United at their place this campaign, so Roberto Mancini's band should have a tough time defending their unbeaten Premier League record. After the disappointing draws with West Ham and Ajax in the Champions League that compounded a turbulent week, the manager did not appear for his pre-game press conference on Friday. We are told he was merely busy elsewhere – as a fortnight has passed since City last won a game and with David Silva, Mancini's go-to lock-picker doubtful as he recovers from a hamstring problem, the Italian may have been plotting how to get his side finally to spark. Jamie Jackson

Alan Pardew has fuelled the fire before Sunday's visit of West Ham by declaring his intention to sign Andy Carroll when his loan deal expires. The fixture was already set to be a lively affair, with both Pardew and Sam Allardyce facing their former employers. Allardyce will be keen to seek revenge following his dismissal in 2008, his opposite number being the man Mike Ashley lined up to replace him. Both sides are struggling defensively, which could mean plenty of goals at St James' Park. West Ham wait on fitness tests for James Collins and James Tomkins, while Newcastle are without the suspended duo of Fabricio Coloccini and Cheik Tioté, Newcastle's two key defensive players. Their absence gives a boost to the visitors' physical approach, which has not been particularly successful away from home; a 2-1 victory at QPR is their only away success to date. Up against a depleted Newcastle recovering from a midweek trip to Belgium, Allardyce could rectify West Ham's away form, and make a victorious return. Alex Keble

it is not uncommon for a derby to be characterised by tension but this meeting of north London's most prominent clubs has a particularly fraught feel to it. The hosts have made their worst start to a league campaign under Arsène Wenger's management and confidence is fragile within a team that has blown a two-goal lead in their last two games. Tottenham, too, have their difficulties, having lost their last two league games and, like Arsenal, their defence continues to appear vulnerable. Goals are practically guaranteed. Sachin Nakrani

They are both 39-years-old, both previously managed Swansea and, although only one is actually from Spain, both speak fluent Spanish. Brendan Rodgers and Roberto Martínez have much in common; these two football purists were the leading candidates to succeed Kenny Dalglish at Anfield last summer. In the end Martínez stayed put at Wigan, leaving Rodgers striving to reprise Liverpool's former glories. With the Merseysiders stuck in 13th place, Saturday promises to be tricky; Wigan won at Anfield last season and once again much may hinge on Luis Suárez. Louise Taylor

Roberto Mancini breezed into his Friday press conference wearing a David Platt mask to poke fun at himself and illustrate a lighter mood after recent travails during which he sent his assistant to speak with the media. Manchester City's manager protects the Premier League's only unbeaten record against a team defeated 4-1 in the corresponding fixture last season, though Aston Villa's recent form has them a place above the drop zone. After Maicon helped inspire Sunday's 3-2 win over Tottenham when entering as a substitute the Brazilian may start, while Mario Balotelli, dropped from the squad for that game due to attitude issues, will hope for a return. Jamie Jackson

Newcastle may have exceeded expectations by finishing fifth last season, but aspire to more than their current position of 10th. However, Sunday's home defeat to West Ham has ruffled Magpie feathers and the continued absence of the suspended Fabricio Coloccini is compounded todayon Saturday by Yohan Cabaye missing out through injury. Their squad depth is being tested. Swansea would be happy to end up where they are now – 11th – and Michael Laudrup's improving side will hope to take advantage of any home uncertainty. Paul Chronnell

Norwich should probably not get too excited if they take the lead against Manchester United, Sir Alex Ferguson's side having come from behind to win numerous times this season. Aston Villa felt United's powers of recovery last week, letting a two-goal lead slip, but perhaps Norwich, unbeaten in their past five matches, are made of sterner stuff. Much will depend on how Chris Hughton's improving side handle the in-form Javier Hernández, who is expected to be handed a rare Premier League start after scoring seven goals in his past five games. Jacob Steinberg

The stakes are high in a clash that has been dubbed "El Sackico" and Nigel Adkins is entitled to approach it with more confidence that Mark Hughes even if Southampton have yet to win away this season. At least his team has shown cohesion and attacking menace, whereas QPR have struggled to score and only intermittently suggested they are playing to a plan. Having said that, both teams have an alarming propensity to sabotage themselves with mistakes so the result is difficult to predict. A draw would be no surprise. Paul Doyle

Reading's manager Brian McDermott has had his say after his side were booed off by their own supporters at the end of last Saturday's goalless draw with Norwich, but the message from impatient terraces and boardroom alike is clear: a first league win of the season is overdue. Can it come at the 12th time of asking? Everton are aiming to maintain an impressive start that sees them in fourth place and, while they will be without Kevin Mirallas on Saturday, they are finding goals easy to come by. Reading's wait may go on. Paul Chronnell

Given Roberto Di Matteo is facing the club that sacked him and Steve Clarke coming up against one he used to play for and coach at, it is no surprise that the respective managers, who also happen to be former Stamford Bridge team-mates, took centre stage ahead of this match. Yet the real intrigue lies in the form of both teams, with Chelsea arriving at The Hawthorns having failed to win any of their past three league games and the hosts looking to win their third match in a row and subsequently move within a point of the European champions. Sachin Nakrani

Martin O'Neill arrives at Craven Cottage yearning for a change in fortunes. His side have won only once in the Premier League since March, Sunderland having lost their last three games in all competitions and with confidence clearly fragile. "We need to win some football matches and the sooner we do that, the better," said the manager. "We have to look at points on the board now at this stage and start galvanising ourselves." A confrontation with an expansive Fulham side, inspired by Dimitar Berbatov and the ever improving Bryan Ruiz, feels daunting – only Manchester United have scored more often than Martin Jol's team. O'Neill's luck may have to be in. Dominic Fifield

West Ham aim to consolidate their place in the top six, which would set them fair for a tilt at European football. This was not part of the script upon the London club's promotion but they have thrived as one of the season's surprise packages. Sam Allardyce's signings have been astute, individual form and confidence are positive and expectations have been readjusted, although not within the squad; they always believed they would shine. Stoke, however, are past masters at jolting opponents to earth and the captain Ryan Shawcross is buoyed by becoming a full England international. David Hytner

Arsenal's injury list has lessened slightly after the nadir of last week's north london derby with Tottenham, a match that Arsène Wenger's side would certainly have found a much tougher assignment were it not for Emmanuel Adebayor's moment of madness. Althout the visitors are still without Theo Walcott and Abou Diaby among others, they should still have enough about them to provide a severe test for Paul Lambert's floundering side, who are themselves coming off the back of the morale-shredding 5-0 drubbing at Manchester City last week. Rich Flower

David Moyes has several injury concerns plus a one-match ban for Marouane Fellaini to contend with against an in-form Norwich team that has not conceded a goal in three matches or lost in six, an impressive sequence that includes wins over Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. The Everton manager was incensed with last week's defeat at Reading – "we abused an opportunity," as he put it – and his team badly need to rediscover their early season momentum. Norwich keeper John Ruddy is expected to recover from a knee injury suffered in the United win in time to face his former club. Andy Hunter

Sir Alex Ferguson has seen Queens Park Rangers remove Mark Hughes on the eve of their trip to Old Trafford and now believes even more that a win against the bottom club should be regulation, especially as there is not yet a Harry Redknapp or any other permanent successor to provide the 'bounce' factor that can often lift players after a managerial sacking. Instead, Mark Bowen and Eddie Niedzwiecki, Hughes' long-term lieutenants, take charge against United, who have lost their last two in all competitions. This all points to a home rout. Jamie Jackson

Fulham's surprise collapse against Sunderland last week means Martin Jol will be demanding a strong response from his players. But it will not be easy – while the visitors' goal haul is second only to Manchester United, away from home they have leaked goals in every match. With Stoke holding the best defensive home record in the league, it could be a tough ask for Dimitar Berbatov to inspire Fulham's depleted squad. Stoke have their own injury concern – Andy Wilkinson may miss out after limping off at West Ham on Monday with a back problem. Rob Clyne

Martin O'Neill and Steve Clarke sat alongside each other at Upton Park on Monday night watching West Ham draw with Stoke and they will be back in close proximity on Saturday. While Clarke's slick counter-attacking visitors aim to enhance an unlikely European challenge, Sunderland could do with building on last Sunday's restorative win at Fulham. With Albion's Shane Long, currently challenging Luis Suárez's mantle as the division's hottest striker, O'Neill must trust his own centre-forward, Steven Fletcher, is in the mood to remind everyone precisely why he cost £12m. Louise Taylor

Jason Roberts, who was one of the scorers in a Wigan victory over Reading that secured their promotion to the Premier League in May 2005, returns to pie-land with a Royals team who claimed their first win of the season against Everton last week, and are now unbeaten in their last four. They could be unchanged, while the Latics lost Gary Caldwell with a hamstring problem as well as Ben Watson with a broken leg in last Saturday's defeat at Liverpool. Ryo Miyaichi and Franco di Santo are also doubtful for the visitors. Andy Wilson

While QPR have spared their new manager a game against one of the Manchester giants, there's no such luck for Rafa Benítez. In his first game in charge he welcomes the champions to Stamford Bridge, a team who finished fifth last time he managed a Premier League side back in 2009-10 – coincidentally the last time City got an away win at Chelsea. Both sides will be looking to get over their Champions League disappointment, with only a four-point gap between them, despite all the talk of a crisis at Roman Abramovich's Chelsea. Toby Moses

Such was the brio of Southampton's performance at Queens Park Rangers last week, in a match where their manager's job was said to be in jeopardy, that Nigel Adkins's team go into this game as slight favourites. Newcastle are stuttering and have several key first-team players unavailable through injury while Southampton are playing with a swagger, especially at home. Newcastle should at least provide a home defence that is still to keep a clean sheet with a stiffer test than QPR did, but Southampton look capable of scoring more. Paul Doyle

Brendan Rodgers returns to the Liberty Stadium for the first time since swapping Swansea for Liverpool. A glance at the table would suggest he made the wrong move – Swansea are one place and one point ahead of the Merseysiders – but Rodgers remains optimistic about his current club's prospects, and perhaps should be given they are undefeated in seven league games and have the division's top scorer in Luis Suárez. It was the hosts, however, who won 3-1 when these sides met in the Capital One Cup last month. Sachin Nakrani

Emmanuel Adebayor's sending-off during last week's north London derby undeniably skewed the outcome of a match Arsenal went on to win 5-2, but the reality for Tottenham is that they have lost four of their last five league games and are performing like a team short of belief and purpose. That is in contrast to West Ham, whose spirits are high following a good start to their first season back among the elite, although that is sure to be tested by the tough set of seven fixtures to come. This could prove the easiest of the lot. Sachin Nakrani

It is a measure either of Swansea's success, or of Arsenal's decline, that Michael Laudrup's side arrive at the Emirates on Saturday just one point and one place behind their hosts. Laudrup would surely prefer the former description, with Wednesday's 3-1 defeat of high-flying West Bromwich Albion confirming that the Dane has maintained the attacking vibrancy Swansea had under Brendan Rodgers last season. After two hard-fought away draws, Arsène Wenger promises Arsenal will thrive in December. A win on Saturday would be the ideal start. Paul Chronnell

It will be a meeting of many old friends at Craven Cottage with Mousa Dembélé and Clint Dempsey returning to face the club they left for Tottenham in the summer, while Fulham's Martin Jol and Dimitar Berbatov will spark a few fond memories among those in the away end. Despite a fine – if largely unnoticed – display against Chelsea in midweek, the Cottagers are at their lowest ebb of the season so far in terms of league position and they will find it tough against a visiting side looking to extend their winning run to three games. John Ashdown

Given Southampton's manager, Nigel Adkins, and their top-scorer, Rickie Lambert, are self-confessed Liverpool supporters it is fair to say this is a fixture with significant meaning for leading figures among the visitors' ranks. Their focus, however, is on securing a fifth match without defeat and clambering out of the relegation zone. Much is at stake for the hosts, too, whose own unbeaten run was ended at White Hart Lane in midweek. Home spirits should be lifted, however, by the return of Lucas Leiva from a long-term thigh injury. Sachin Nakrani

Manchester City have already passed the first test of champions hoping to retain their title: that of staying among the leaders as Christmas approaches despite failing to hit top form. In fact, Roberto Mancini's team are only a point behind Manchester United with a goal difference that is better by two ahead of Everton's arrival at the Etihad Stadium on Saturday. David Moyes's side have defeated Mancini's City on five of the six occasions they have met and the Toffees should once again prove to be a tricky proposition for the home side. Jamie Jackson

Harry Redknapp will get a rousing reception from QPR supporters desperate for a saviour. Attempts to win their first match of the season against fellow relegation worriers Reading and Southampton, at home under Mark Hughes, ended badly, and the hosts can ill afford to make it third time unlucky. Aston Villa beat Reading in midweek but have not won successive Premier League matches for over a year. Neither team is scoring freely and by the end, it will be interesting to see who has the greater need for Darren Bent. Amy Lawrence

There have been four top-flight games between these sides and Reading can take heart from the draws they have achieved on two of those occasions. Less heartening, however, is the Royals' current league position – they are 19th having won only once all season and now come up against a Manchester United side who lead the division despite not having clicked into high gear. Sir Alex Ferguson will expect three points before resting his big guns for Wednesday's Champions League dead rubber against CFR Cluj. Jamie Jackson

Such has been West Bromwich Albion's excellent start to the season that their defeat at Swansea on Wednesday came as something of a surprise, despite the Liberty Stadium being a ground where Chelsea and Liverpool have failed to win recently. The setback provides Steve Clarke with a chance to see the resolve of his high-flying squad and they will certainly not get an easy ride against Stoke, who are unbeaten in four games but without Peter Crouch after he broke three teeth in a clash with Newcastle's Fabricio Coloccini in midweek. Sachin Nakrani

Trips to the Boleyn Ground have represented easy pickings for Chelsea in recent times, with only two points shed in their last six visits. Perhaps that was why Sam Allardyce sounded a note of caution ahead of this derby despite the fact the visitors arrive without a win in six league games and with fans still deeply unsettled by the arrival of Rafael Benítez. "Rafa has already sorted out what was a problem under Roberto [Di Matteo]," said Allardyce, reflecting upon Chelsea's successive goalless draws under the Spaniard.
